multiple-choice.question: What is the longest recorded case of hiccups in a person?

options.label: A
options.text: 50 times per minute for more than four weeks

options.label: C
options.text: 100 times per minute for more than two weeks

options.label: D
options.text: 20 times per minute for more than one week

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what are some common stimuli that can cause hiccups?

options.label: B
options.text: Swallowing air, rapid eating or drinking, intense emotions, or anxiety

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the diaphragm during a hiccup?

options.label: B
options.text: To initiate a sudden intake of air

options.label: D
options.text: To prevent air from entering the lungs

multiple-choice.question: What is the possible evolutionary explanation for the origin of hiccups?

options.label: A
options.text: Hiccups are a vestigial remnant from our evolutionary past

options.label: B
options.text: Hiccups are a relic of the ancient transition from water to land

options.label: C
options.text: Hiccups are a result of the rapid changes faced by frogs today

options.label: D
options.text: Hiccups are a result of the abundant oxygen in the air overhead

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the neural patterning involved in generating a hiccup?

options.label: A
options.text: It is almost identical to that responsible for respiration in humans

options.label: B
options.text: It is almost identical to that responsible for respiration in amphibians

options.label: C
options.text: It is completely different from that responsible for respiration in humans

options.label: D
options.text: It is not related to respiration in any way

multiple-choice.question: What is the possible advantage of hiccups in mammals?

options.label: A
options.text: To help remove air from the stomach as a sort of glorified burp

options.label: B
options.text: To help remove milk from the stomach as a sort of glorified burp

options.label: C
options.text: To help remove oxygen from the lungs as a sort of glorified cough

options.label: D
options.text: To help remove carbon dioxide from the lungs as a sort of glorified cough

multiple-choice.question: What is the possible explanation for the retention of the hiccup reflex in mammals?

options.label: A
options.text: It is retained because it provides an important advantage

options.label: B
options.text: It is retained because it is a vestigial remnant from our evolutionary past

options.label: C
options.text: It is retained because it is a result of the rapid changes faced by frogs today

options.label: D
options.text: It is retained because it is a result of the abundant oxygen in the air overhead

multiple-choice.question: What is one home remedy that has not been verified to work consistently?

options.label: A
options.text: Sipping continuously from a glass of cold water

options.label: C
options.text: A mouthful of honey or peanut butter

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the characteristic sound associated with hiccups?
What is the possible explanation for the fact that hiccups are found only in mammals?

options.label: A
options.text: It is because hiccups are a vestigial remnant from our evolutionary past

options.label: B
options.text: It is because hiccups are a relic of the ancient transition from water to land

options.label: C
options.text: It is because hiccups are a result of the rapid changes faced by frogs today

options.label: D
options.text: It is because hiccups are a uniquely mammalian activity

multiple-choice.question: What is one idea about the evolutionary origin of hiccups?

options.label: A
options.text: Hiccups began many millions of years before the appearance of humans

options.label: B
options.text: Hiccups are a vestigial remnant from our evolutionary past

options.label: C
options.text: Hiccups are a result of the rapid changes faced by frogs today

options.label: D
options.text: Hiccups are a result of the abundant oxygen in the air overhead

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what happens when a bout of hiccups continues for a long time?

options.label: A
options.text: Home remedies like sipping cold water, holding one's breath, or breathing into a paper bag may work

options.label: B
options.text: The hiccup reflex is retained in mammals because it provides an important advantage

options.label: C
options.text: The neural patterning involved in generating a hiccup is almost identical to that responsible for respiration in humans

options.label: D
options.text: The characteristic sound associated with hiccups is "Hoo"

title: Don't eat the marshmallow!

multiple-choice.question: Who conducted the experiment involving children and marshmallows?

options.label: A
options.text: A psychology professor from Stanford University

multiple-choice.question: What was the task given to the four-year-old children in the experiment?

options.label: B
options.text: To wait 15 minutes for another marshmallow

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of children who did not eat the marshmallow were successful 15 years later?
According to the speaker, what is the most important principle for success?

options.label: A
options.text: Being able to make quick decisions

options.label: C
options.text: Having good relationships with teachers and students

multiple-choice.question: How did the Hispanic children in Colombia react to the marshmallow experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: Two out of three ate the marshmallow, and one out of three did not

options.label: B
options.text: One out of three ate the marshmallow, and two out of three did not

options.label: C
options.text: All of them ate the marshmallow

options.label: D
options.text: None of them ate the marshmallow

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a salesperson who did not "eat the marshmallow"?

options.label: A
options.text: One who asks the customer questions before making a sale

options.label: B
options.text: One who immediately gives the customer what they want

options.label: C
options.text: One who tries to upsell the customer

options.label: D
options.text: One who does not make a sale

multiple-choice.question: What is the implication of the speaker's statement that "we are eating more marshmallows than we are producing"?

options.label: A
options.text: That we are producing more than we are consuming

options.label: B
options.text: That we are consuming more than we are producing

options.label: C
options.text: That we are producing and consuming equally

options.label: D
options.text: That we are not producing or consuming anything

multiple-choice.question: What is a key aspect of the principle of delaying gratification?

options.label: A
options.text: Being patient and waiting for what you want

options.label: B
options.text: Being impulsive and acting on impulse

options.label: D
options.text: Not making any decisions at all

multiple-choice.question: What method did the speaker use to teach children the principle of delaying gratification?

options.label: A
options.text: By giving them a book to read about the principle

options.label: B
options.text: By using a book to teach them the principle

options.label: C
options.text: By not teaching them the principle at all

options.label: D
options.text: By letting them watch a video about the principle

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's opinion on the importance of teaching children the principle of delaying gratification?

options.label: A
options.text: He thinks it is not important

options.label: B
options.text: He thinks it is somewhat important

options.label: C
options.text: He thinks it is very important

options.label: D
options.text: He thinks it is the most important principle for success

multiple-choice.question: Why did the speaker conduct the marshmallow experiment in Colombia?

options.label: A
options.text: To compare the results with the American children

options.label: B
options.text: To test the principle of delaying gratification in a different culture

options.label: C
options.text: To see if the children in Colombia would eat the marshmallow

options.label: D
options.text: To teach the children in Colombia the principle of delaying gratification

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's opinion on the success of the children who did not eat the marshmallow?

options.label: A
options.text: He thinks they will have trouble in life

options.label: B
options.text: He thinks they will be successful

options.label: C
options.text: He thinks they will be average

title: Why the metric system matters - Matt Anticole

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary reason for the French Revolution's focus on transforming the system of measurements?

options.label: A
options.text: To overthrow the monarchy and gain power

options.label: B
options.text: To promote standard decimal-based measures and rational principles

options.label: C
options.text: To standardize measurements for political advantages and to transform society according to the rational principles of the Enlightenment

options.label: D
options.text: To adopt a new Republican Calendar and reduce church power

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the system of measurement defined by the French Revolution?
According to the Marquis de Condorcet, what was the purpose of the new metric system?

options.label: B
options.text: For all people, for all time

options.label: C
options.text: To extract more rent from commoners

multiple-choice.question: How did the adoption of the metric system benefit the French government's ability to collect taxes?

options.label: B
options.text: It enabled the government to collect taxes more efficiently

options.label: D
options.text: It reduced the government's ability to collect taxes

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary reason for the United States' resistance to adopting the metric system?

options.label: B
options.text: Intuition of units like feet and pounds

multiple-choice.question: How did the French Revolution's focus on standardizing measurements affect the nobility?

options.label: A
options.text: It allowed them to extract more rent from commoners

options.label: B
options.text: It reduced their power and influence

options.label: C
options.text: It had no effect on their power and influence

options.label: D
options.text: It increased their power and influence

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the speed of light in the development of the metric system?

options.label: A
options.text: It was used as a universal constant to define standards

options.label: B
options.text: It was used to calculate the length of a meter

options.label: C
options.text: It was used to measure the weight of a grain

options.label: D
options.text: It was used to determine the Equator's distance from the North Pole

multiple-choice.question: What is the current status of the metric system in the United States?

options.label: D
options.text: It is widely used in science and medicine, but not fully adopted

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary advantage of the metric system's adoption in the British Empire?

options.label: C
options.text: It enabled the government to collect taxes more efficiently

options.label: D
options.text: It allowed small businesses to use traditional measurements

multiple-choice.question: How has the metric system evolved over time?

options.label: A
options.text: It has remained unchanged since its introduction

options.label: B
options.text: It has been replaced with a new system

options.label: C
options.text: It has been updated to include new standards based on universal constants

multiple-choice.question: Why did the United States of America stick with the English units of its colonial past?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of its fear of global conformity

options.label: B
options.text: Because of its intuition of units like feet and pounds

options.label: C
options.text: Because of its colonial past and traditional units

multiple-choice.question: What was the reason for the French Revolution's focus on replacing old standards based on arbitrary authority or local traditions with mathematical and natural relationships?

options.label: A
options.text: To overthrow the monarchy and gain power

options.label: B
options.text: To promote standard decimal-based measures and rational principles

options.label: C
options.text: To standardize measurements for political advantages and to transform society

options.label: D
options.text: To adopt a new Republican Calendar and reduce church power

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what was the result of the French Revolution's focus on standardizing measurements?

options.label: A
options.text: It had no effect on the nobility

options.label: B
options.text: It reduced their power and influence

options.label: C
options.text: It increased their power and influence

options.label: D
options.text: It allowed them to extract more rent from commoners

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the metric system's adoption in the British Empire?

options.label: C
options.text: It enabled the government to collect taxes more efficiently

options.label: D
options.text: It allowed small businesses to use traditional measurements

multiple-choice.question: How did the French Revolution's focus on standardizing measurements affect the adoption of the metric system in other countries?

options.label: B
options.text: It slowed down the adoption of the metric system

options.label: C
options.text: It sped up the adoption of the metric system

options.label: D
options.text: It led to the rejection of the metric system
